titleStmt.title: Pinning Stabilization of Linearly Coupled Stochastic Neural Networks via Minimum Number of Controllers

affiliation.orgName: Department of Information Systems and Com-puting
Nanjing University of Science and Technology

analytic.title: Pinning Stabilization of Linearly Coupled Stochastic Neural Networks via Minimum Number of Controllers

biblStruct.note: received May 21, 2008; revised March 27, 2009 and May 27, 2009; accepted June 09, 2009. First published August 25, 2009; current version

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Pinning stabilization problem of linearly coupled stochastic neural networks (LCSNNs) is studied in this paper. A minimum number of controllers are used to force the LCSNNs to the desired equilibrium point by fully utilizing the structure of the network. In order to pinning control the LCSNNs to a certain desired state, only one controller is required for strongly connected network topology, and controllers, which will be shown to be the minimum number, are needed for LCSNNs with -reducible coupling matrix. The isolate node of the LCSNNs can be stable, periodic, or even chaotic. The coupling Laplacian matrix of the LCSNNs can be symmetric irreducible, asymmetric irreducible, or -reducible, which means that the network topology can be strongly connected, weakly connected, or even unconnected. There is no constraint on the network topology. Some criteria are derived to judge whether the LCSNNs can be controlled in mean square by using designed controllers. The given criteria are expressed in terms of strict linear matrix inequalities, which can be easily checked by resorting to recently developed algorithm. Moreover, numerical examples including small-world and scale-free networks are also given to demonstrate that our theoretical results are valid and efficient for large systems.

physically implement and hence have promising applications especially in secure communications based on synchronization [12]- [14]. In synthetic biology, it is also a central issue to understand how the cellular behavior emerges from these networks of interactions [15], [16]. Hence, in this paper, synchronization problem of linearly coupled NNs will be studied. Since time delay is ubiquitous in many biological systems due to the finite signal propagation time and may cause undesirable dynamical behavior such as oscillation and instability, time delay will be introduced into the modeling of NNs. On the other hand, stochastic neural networks (SNNs) have become a new research subject [17]. Hence, an array of linearly coupled stochastic delayed NNs, in which stochastic disturbance is characterized by multidimensional Brownian motion, will be considered.

Synchronization mentioned above is achieved by the local connections of the nodes, and no external force is utilized. In the following, such a synchronous state is named as "final selfsynchronized state." However, the final self-synchronized state, which depends not only on the initial values and intrinsic dynamical behavior of each single node but also on the topology of the coupling network, is very difficult to predict. For many physical, social, and biological dynamical networks, there is a common requirement to regulate the behavior of large ensembles of interacting units by external forces [18]- [20]. For instance, many regulatory mechanisms have been uncovered in the context of biological, physiological, and cellular processes, which are fundamental to guarantee the correct functioning of the whole network [19], [21]. Moreover, in [22], the control method is selected as one of the four key features to understand biology systems at system level. Hence, it is desirable to add some controllers to force the entire LCSNNs to certain given objectives (named as "pinning stabilization").

Motivated by the above discussion, pinning stabilization of LCSNNs will be considered in this paper. By referring to the pinning idea in [23]- [25], some local controllers will be pinned to certain selected NNs. It means that only a small fraction of the NNs will be informed about the objective state and the state will be propagated to the rest of the NNs through the local connections.

Recently, some papers have been engaged in the issue of pinning control of linearly coupled systems [23]- [25]. Chen et al. laid a fundamental work for pinning control of complex dynamical networks in [24], in which a single controller is designed for the pinning control of connected networks. The key point about pinning control of networks is indicated and proved in [24] that all the eigenvalues of the controlled coupling matrix [i.e., in (12)] are negative. The problem of pinning controllability of complex network is investigated by using the spectral properties of an extended network topology [26]. However, the number of the controllers in [18] and [23] is quite large, and stochastic disturbance is not taken into account in [23] and [24]. Then, the question is: Can we reduce the number of controllers for the pinning stabilization of LCSNNs? This is exactly one of the objectives of this paper, and these problems are to be addressed by fully utilizing the structure of the network.

Therefore, we will extend the idea of [24] to the case of coupled SNNs. Further, by referring to the structure of coupling networks, the minimum number of controllers will be constructed for the pinning stabilization of LCSNNs. The topology of the coupling network can be arbitrary without any restriction. The remainder of this paper will be organized as follows. In Section II, the model formulation of LCSNNs and some preliminaries will be presented. In Section III, the pinning stabilization problem of LCSNNs with, respectively, symmetric irreducible coupling matrix, asymmetric irreducible coupling matrix, and -reducible coupling matrix will be studied, and some criteria will be derived in terms of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs) to guarantee the success of designed controller. In Section IV, several computer numerical simulations will be given to demonstrate the validity of the theoretical analysis, and Section V concludes the investigation.

Notations: The standard notations will be used in this paper. Throughout this paper, for real symmetric matrices and , the notation (respectively, ) means that the matrix is negative semidefinite (respectively, negative definite).

is the identity matrix of order . We use and to denote the minimum and maximum eigenvalue of a real symmetric matrix, respectively. The notation denotes Euclidean norm of vector , and means the maximum element of vector . denotes the set of real numbers. are real matrices. The superscript " " represents the transpose.

stands for a block-diagonal matrix. denotes the mathematical expectation operator with respect to the given probability measure . To differentiate vectors from scalars, bold font is used to denote vectors; matrices, if not explicitly stated, they are assumed to have compatible dimensions.

div.head: II. MODEL FORMULATION AND SOME PRELIMINARIES
div.p: Some preliminary knowledge is presented in this section for the derivation of our main results. The deterministic NN can be described by the following delayed differential equation [27]:
(1) or (2) where represents the number of neurons in the network, is the state vector associated with the neurons, and corresponds to the activation function of neurons.

is a positive diagonal matrix, and and are the connection weight matrix and the delayed connection matrix, respectively. is a constant external input vector, and is the transmission delay. The initial conditions of (1) are given by , where means the set of continuous functions from to . For the activation function , we have the following Lipschitz assumption.
Assumption 1: The neuron activation function of the NN satisfies the following Lipschitz condition:

where is a positive constant for . For convenience, let . Remark 1: In many literatures, the activation function is typically assumed to be continuous, differentiable, and monotonically increasing, such as the function of sigmoid type. In this paper, these constraints have been removed, and only the Lipschitz condition is imposed in Assumption 1. It should be noted that the type of activation function in (3) has been used in numerous papers.

As discussed in Section I, in the real world, the NN is often disturbed by environmental noise that affects the dynamical behavior of the system. In this paper, as in [17] and [28]- [31], the stochastic perturbation is introduced into the recurrent NN as follows: (4) where is an -dimensional Brownian motion defined on a complete probability space with filtration satisfying the usual conditions (i.e., the filtration contains all -null sets and is right continuous). Here, the white noise is independent of for , and is named the noise intensity function matrix. This kind of stochastic disturbance can be regarded as a result of the occurrence of random uncertainties of the NN.

In this paper, we consider a kind of complex dynamical network by setting each node to be a stochastic neural network (SNN). The th SNN can be expressed by the following delayed stochastic differential equation (SDE):
(5) where is the state vector of the th NN, and is an -dimensional Brownian motion defined on a complete probability space with nature filtration .

When stochastic neural networks (SNNs) are linearly coupled via a complex network, we can obtain the linearly coupled stochastic neural networks (LCSNNs) described by the following linearly coupled SDEs: (6) where is the state vector of the th delayed SNN, is the inner coupling matrix between two connected NNs for all , is the coupling strength of the LCSNNs, is the Laplacian matrix representing the coupling structure of the LCSNNs [32], and the elements in matrix are defined as follows: if there is a connection from NN to NN , then ; otherwise, , and the diffusive coupling condition is satisfied, which implies that the LCSNNs would be decoupled when the array is synchronized.

In this paper, we want to control the LCSNNs (6) to the desired state , which is an equilibrium point of NN (1). As discussed in many other papers, the stochastic perturbation vanishes at this equilibrium point , that is, . For notational convenience, one can shift the equilibrium point to the origin by using the translation and the equality , which derives the following stochastic dynamical system: (7) where , , and
. The initial functions in (7) are given by , where denotes the family of all -measurable -valued stochastic processes such that .

Assume that the noise intensity function matrix is uniformly Lipschitz continuous satisfying the following linear growth condition [33], [34]: (8) where and are known constant matrices with compatible dimensions.

Remark 2: The condition (8) on the noise intensity function matrix guarantees that elements of are limited in how fast they can change [35]. A convenient sufficient condition for satisfaction of condition ( 8) is that elements of matrix function are differentiable maps with bounded partial derivative of first order. This assumption has been widely used for an elementary proof of the existence and uniqueness of solutions of SDEs [36], and also for the stability analysis of SDEs [17], [29], [30]. In fact, under conditions ( 3) and ( 8), ( 5) has a unique continuous solution on [33]. In order to synchronize the LCSNN (6) to the equilibrium point , equivalently, one can synchronize the LCSNN (7) to the origin due to the transformation. Hence, in the remainder of this paper, controllers will be designed for the stabilization of LCSNN ( 7) in mean square. The controlled LCSNNs can be described by the coupled SDE (9) The following definitions and lemmas are needed for the derivation of our main results in this paper.

Definition 1: The pinning controlled LCSNNs ( 9) is said to be globally exponentially synchronized at the original point in mean square, if for any given initial condition, there exist positive constants and such that , where is the mathematical expectation. Definition 2: Matrix is said to be reducible if it can be transformed to a matrix of the form by the same permutation of the rows and columns, where and are square matrices and is a null matrix. An irreducible matrix is a matrix which is not reducible.
Remark 3: A network is strongly connected if and only if the corresponding Laplacian matrix is irreducible.

Lemma 2 (Gershgorin's Circle Theorem) [38]: For an matrix , define . Then, each eigenvalue of is in at least one of the disks . div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, three different types of coupling network topologies, the Laplacian matrices of which are respectively symmetric irreducible, asymmetric irreducible, and -reducible (refer to Definition 4 in Section III-C), will be considered.

div.head: A. Symmetric Irreducible Coupling
div.p: In this section, coupling matrix is assumed to be symmetric and irreducible, and pinning stabilization issue of LCSNNs with such coupling matrix in mean square will be investigated. In fact, symmetric irreducible coupling matrix implies that the corresponding coupling network is undirected and strongly connected. For the pinning stabilization of the LCSNNs ( 7) with symmetric irreducible coupling matrix , the controller is added to the th NN with the concrete form as follows: otherwise (10) where is a positive constant. It means that only the first NN is selected to be controlled to stabilize the LCSNNs with symmetric irreducible coupling matrix to the desired equilibrium point in mean square. By using controller (10), the feedback controlled LCSNNs can be described by the following delayed SDEs: (11) where the elements of matrix are defined as follows:
otherwise. ( 12)

Theorem 1: If there exist positive scalars , , , and , and a diagonal positive-definite matrix such that LMI (13) shown at the bottom of the page, and LMIs ( 14) and (15) hold, where , then the controlled LCSNNs ( 9) with symmetric irreducible coupling matrix is globally exponentially stabilized by controller (10) in mean square.

Proof: According to the structure of the matrix , one has that , and for . Due to the irreducibility of matrix , it follows from Lemma 1 that the determinant of matrix is not equal to zero. By referring to Gershgorin's circle theorem (Lemma 2), we can obtain . Here, we used Lemma 1 and Gershgorin's circle theorem to prove that . It should be noted that the fact that all eigenvalues of the matrix are negative has been proved in [24,Prop. 1]. Proposition 1 of [24] is a result for the case of real matrices, and its proof is better presentable and easier to understand. Since , it is reasonable to require that LMI (13) holds, that is, . Pre-and postmultiplying ( 13) by the following block-diagonal matrix: one can obtain LMI ( 16), shown at the bottom of the page. Since , by using Schur complement [39], one can conclude that ( 16) holds if and only if with . Then, we can obtain that (17) By (17), there exists a sufficient small positive constant such that (13) (16) (18) Define a Lyapunov functional as follows: (19) where and . By using Itô's differential formula [33], the stochastic derivative of along the controlled LCSNNs (11) with symmetric irreducible coupling matrix can be expressed as follows: (20) Noticing that and are both diagonal positive-definite matrices, we have the following inequality: (21) where for , and LMI ( 14) is used.
By using Lemma 4 and Assumption 1, one can obtain the following inequalities for and :
It follows from condition (8) and LMI ( 17) that (24) By using the inequalities (21), - (24), one can obtain from ( 20) that (25) where is defined as in (18), and is used.

From (18), we see that . Then, by taking the mathematical expectation of both sides of (25), one can obtain that (26) which implies that (27) Therefore, we obtain that (28) which further means that (29) where . Therefore, by Definition 1, it can be concluded that the controlled LCSNN (11) with symmetric irreducible coupling matrix is globally exponentially stable in mean square, which implies that the LCSNN (9) with symmetric irreducible coupling matrix has been globally exponentially stabilized to the desired point in mean square by using the single controller (10) acting on the first NN. The proof of this theorem is completed.

Remark 4: The constraint that matrix is required to be diagonal could lead the result in Theorem 1 to be conservative. For master-slave synchronization of time-delay systems, such requirement can be easily removed to make results less conservative. However, different from master-slave synchronization of two coupled systems, the diagonal constraint of matrix in Theorem 1 comes from the special structure of LCSNNs. If matrix is not assumed to be diagonal, it would be very hard to distill from by referring to inequality (21), in which is used to characterize the controllability of LCSNNs. We will think about this issue in our future research to make results less conservative.

Remark 5: It should be noted that the size of our results ( 13)-( 15) is independent of the network size, because the largest eigenvalue has been distilled to characterize the controllability of LCSNNs. In fact, the size of derived LMI criteria is at most five times of the dimension of each individual system ( in this paper), which is usually quite small comparing with the ability of Matlab LMI Toolbox. Hence, our LMI results are feasible and efficient for large networks coupled with low-dimension NNs. However, for some classes of NNs possessing a large number of neurons (i.e., is very big), the order of LMIs ( 13)-(15) will be very high. In the circumstance, it could be hard for Matlab LMI Toolbox to find feasible solutions to high-order LMIs. From this point of view, we derive an algebraic criterion in Corollary 1, which is more conservative but much easier to be verified for NNs composed of large number of neurons. For the algebraic criterion in Corollary 1, only eigenvalues of large scale matrix are needed to be computed, which implies that such criterion is applicable even for NNs with large number of neurons.

Corollary 1: The controlled LCSNN (9) with symmetric irreducible coupling matrix is globally exponentially stabilized by the controller (10) in mean square if the following inequality holds: (30) Proof: Using Schur complement, this corollary can be proved directly by taking , , and in Theorem 1. Detailed proof is omitted here. Remark 6: We point out that can be regarded as a function of , that is, , and further is decreasing with respect to . (In fact, for two given constants , one can have and . Here, with

. By Rayleigh quotient, one has that Therefore, it can be concluded that controller (10) with feedback strength is valid if feedback strength has been verified to be successful. Based on our criteria, the lower bound of feedback strength can be numerically obtained. It should be noted that our obtained lower bound is not the actual one, because our criteria are only sufficient but not sufficient and necessary. Explicit expression of successful feedback strength cannot be obtained since analytical relation between and cannot be derived. Remark 7: Note that the idea behind the controller is that a reference state is introduced only for one NN (the first NN in Theorem 1) which will play a key role for the spread of the reference state. If the LCSNNs is connected tightly enough [i.e., LMIs ( 13)-( 15) hold], the reference state will be propagated efficiently and hence the whole LCSNNs will be directed to the desired state successfully. Remark 8: Only one controller is utilized for the stabilization of LCSNNs with symmetric irreducible coupling matrix in Theorem 1. Moreover, at least one controller is needed for such a purpose, since the self-synchronized state of LCSNNs cannot be predicted and one cannot guarantee it to be the objective equilibrium point. Hence, a minimum number of controllers have been used to synchronize the LCSNNs with symmetric irreducible coupling matrix in mean square.

Remark 9: For some real-world cases, the state variable of NN cannot be observed directly, and hence, the LCSNN is coupled through the output of each NN . This means that the coupling term " " should be replaced by "

," where is the output of NN . From the mathematical point of view, there is no difficulty in generalizing the result in Theorem 1 to the output symmetric coupling case, if the nonlinear function satisfies certain conditions given in [24,Th. 4], or [40] and [41].

div.head: B. Asymmetric Irreducible Coupling
div.p: The pinning stabilization issue of LCSNNs with asymmetric irreducible coupling matrix in mean square will be studied in this section. The asymmetric irreducible coupling matrix means that the corresponding coupled network structure is directed and strongly connected. For notational convenience, the following definition is presented.

Definition 3: For an irreducible square matrix with nonnegative off-diagonal elements, the quantity is defined as follows: decompose uniquely as , where is a zero row sum matrix and is a diagonal matrix. Let be the unique normalized left eigenvector of with respect to the eigenvalue zero satisfying , and . Then, . In the following theorem, denote as the normalized left eigenvector of matrix with respect to eigenvalue zero, and .

Similar to Corollary 1, the following corollary can be used in the case of NNs with large number of neurons.

Corollary 2: The LCSNN ( 9) with asymmetric irreducible coupling matrix will be exponentially synchronized to the origin point by controller (10) in mean square if the following inequality holds: (45)

div.head: C. -Reducible Coupling
div.p: In this section, the most general case will be considered. The coupling matrix is assumed to be -reducible. The detailed logistic analysis about why the minimum number is utilized is presented from the systematic point of view. First, the definition of -reducible matrix is given.

Definition 4 [42]: Consider a reducible matrix of order . , , and , then the corresponding network with such coupling matrix is disconnected with two components. If the irreducible matrix is defined as -reducible matrix, then any Laplacian matrix of its corresponding network (including connected and disconnected) can be represented by an -reducible matrix. Hence, any network can be represented by an -reducible matrix, which implies that the result in this section is quite general.

By defining irreducible matrices , , and for , LCSNN (7) with -reducible coupling matrix (46) can be decomposed into the following subnetworks denoted by for . It should be noted that the set contains all the row indexes relative to the states of th subnetwork for (47) and (48) It follows from coupled stochastic differential (48) that the subnetwork with is self-contained, and it cannot be influenced by any individual out of the subnetwork . That is to say, the subnetwork is independent from the rest of the subnetworks. By the definition of -reducible matrix, for each , there exists such that . Hence, one can conclude that the subnetwork must be influenced by the subnetwork . As mentioned in Section I, the final self-synchronized state of the subnetworks with is very difficult to predict especially when the individual NNs are chaotic. Hence, we can always assume that the final self-synchronized state of the subnetworks is unknown in this paper. In order to guarantee that the synchronized state of the subnetwork is consistent with the given state ( in this paper), at least one controller is required to synchronize the self-governed subnetwork to the desired state for each in . Therefore, not less than controllers are needed for the pinning stabilization of the self-governed subnetworks , which implies that at least controllers are required to synchronize the LCSNN (7) with -reducible coupling matrix (46) to the desired state.

In the following, controllers will be constructed to exponentially stabilize the LCSNNs (7) with -reducible coupling matrix (46) under certain conditions, which means that a minimum number of controllers have been used for the pinning stabilization of LCSNNs. The first NN of each self-governed subnetwork is chosen to be controlled, and the additional controllers are in the form of for otherwise.
Then, the controlled LCSNN (9) with controllers (49) can be described by (47) and (50) for Let matrix for , and matrix for such that the elements are defined as follows: otherwise
where . Then, the controlled subnetworks (50) can be rewritten as for

Let matrices be such that (52) for . Denote to be the normalized left eigenvector of matrix with respect to eigenvalue zero, and for . Theorem 3: The LCSNN (9) with -reducible coupling matrix in the form of ( 46) can be exponentially stabilized to the origin by controllers (49) in the mean square, if there exist positive scalars , , , and , and a diagonal positive-definite matrix for such that LMI (53), shown at the bottom of the page, and LMIs 55) hold for , it can be concluded from Theorem 2 that the subnetworks will be globally exponentially stabilized to the origin in mean square.

For subnetwork , by substituting synchronous state into the coupled stochastic dynamical (47), one can obtain the following dynamical system: (56) Also, by using Theorem 2, the subnetwork can be stabilized to the origin in mean square.

By induction, it can be concluded that the whole LCSNNs with -reducible coupling matrix ( 46) can be exponentially stabilized to the origin in mean square by using controllers (49). Since at least controllers are needed for the pinning stabilization of such LCSNNs, according to the above analysis, a minimum number of controllers have been used in this theorem. This completes the proof.
Remark 11: It should be noted that the increment of the constant in controller (49) will make smaller, which further make the convergence rate of the dynamical network larger.

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, two numerical examples will be given to verify the theoretical results obtained above. Consider the following two-order SNN as individual node of the LCSNNs to be discussed in the following two examples:
(57) with parameters where is the state vector of the NN, and . The noise intensity function matrix is taken as By some simple calculations, assumptions (3) and ( 8) are satisfied with

, where is a identity matrix. Without considering the stochastic term in (57), the deterministic NN with the above-given parameters has a chaotic attractor [43] as shown in Fig. 1(a), with initial values , , . The attractor of the SNN (57) is shown in Fig. 1(b) with the same initial condition.
In the numerical simulations, the discretization approach given in [44] is utilized. The dimension of the Brownian motion is selected to be equal to the dimension of the single NN, that is,

. Some initial parameters are given as follows: the simulation time with , the normally distributed variance and step size with , and the number of discretized Brownian paths is . The Euler-Maruyama numerical technique is adopted to simulate the stochastic ordinary differential equations. It should be noted that the numerical solution given by Euler-Maruyama numerical scheme will converge to the true solution of the equilibrium point of the system in an expectation sense as the sampling time step size tends to zero [44], [45].

Example 1: We consider the LCSNNs with -reducible coupling matrix, in which the inner coupling matrix and coupling strength are, respectively, taken as and . In the following simulation, all initial values are randomly selected from the interval . Consider the following -reducible coupling matrix:
(58) Stage I-Add Controllers: The controller (49) with is used, which means that the nodes 3 and 6 (first node of subnetworks 2 and 3) are to be controlled. One can obtain that

div.head: Stage II-Find of Controlled LCSNNs:
div.p: The normalized left eigenvector of corresponding matrices with respect to eigenvalue zero are, respectively, , , and , which implies that , , and . Further, we can obtain that , , and by using Definition 3.

Stage III-Applying Matlab LMI Toolbox to Find Feasible Solution: Given a single NN as described by (57), by referring to the LMI toolbox of Matlab, one can obtain the feasible solution to LMIs (53)-(55) as follows: and and and Hence, by Theorem 3, it can be concluded that the LCSNNs with -reducible coupling matrix (58) can be stabilized to the original point by controllers (49) with , which are pinned in the third node and the sixth node. Fig. 2 plots three independent trajectories of the controlled LCSNNs with independent Brownian motions [see Fig. 2 (a)-(c)], and the corresponding average trajectory of the above three simulations is displayed in Fig. 2(d). Fig. 2 shows the effectiveness of the designed controllers. This example is given to show that our results are applicable and efficient for large networks. It should be noted that the maximum eigenvalue has been distilled to characterize the synchronization controllability of LCSNNs, hence the size of the derived LMIs is not related to the network size anymore. This is exactly the reason why our criteria can be easily verified for large networks.

Stage I-Framework Description: In this example, two practical network models including BA scale free [46] and NW small world [47] will be considered. First, the network is constructed by choosing corresponding parameters and using rules proposed in [46] and [47]. The weight of each edge is assumed to be one, then the corresponding Laplacian matrix has been obtained. Second, the node with maximum degree is selected to be controlled with feedback strength . It means that is obtained. Third, the maximum eigenvalue of , which characterizes the synchronization controllability, is calculated. Since networks generated by scale-free and small-world models are not deterministic, repeated simulations are required to verify our result. Hence, the above three steps are repeated 100 times independently. Finally, with the resulting data, four statistical values including mean, maximum, minimum, and standard deviation are calculated as indexes of its concentration degree.

Stage II-Networks Generation, Add Controller, and the Maximum Eigenvalues Calculation: In the first experiment, scale-free network is considered. The generation of scale-free network is referred to in [46]. Taking , 100 independent scale-free networks are generated with the size being, respectively, 100, 500, and 1000. After adding controllers to the generated networks, the maximum eigenvalues are calculated. Four statistical values are shown in Table I. It can be observed that the standard deviation of the data is quite small, which means that the data are quite concentrated in their distribution.

In the second experiment, small-world network is considered. For the generation of small-world network, refer to [47]. In the simulations, the initial degree of nodes and adding probability of edges are, respectively, chosen as and . Then, 100 independent small-world networks are generated with, respectively, 100, 500, and 1000 nodes. After adding controllers to the generated networks, the maximum eigenvalues are calculated. Table II displays the statistical values of the 100 independent simulation results. Small standard deviation means a high concentration of our obtained maximum eigenvalues.

Stage III-Applying Matlab LMI Toolbox to Find Feasible Solution: Among 600 simulated networks, the maximum eigenvalue is in the case of scale-free network with 1000 nodes. The inner coupling matrix and coupling strength are, respectively, taken as and . Given individual node by (57), by using LMI , and . By Theorem 1, LCSNNs with such network structure can be successfully controlled. From LMI (13), it can be concluded that 600 generated networks can all be controlled, since their maximum eigenvalues are less than . Remark 12: It can be seen from Example 2 that our results are feasible for large scale networks. This is because the maximum eigenvalue calculation of sparse matrix has been well established in Matlab, and then our computation was reduced to small scale LMI problem or algebraic criterion.

Remark 13: It should be noted that one controller cannot be ensured to be successful for arbitrary size of networks when the dynamical network itself is not sufficiently enough interconnected. Take a scale-free network with 5000 nodes as an example, and the of the parameters are the same as in Example 2. The maximum eigenvalue of controlled dynamical networks is under one controller, and the criteria in Theorem 1 cannot be satisfied to guarantee the success of pinning control. However, if the network itself is further tightly connected by taking , it can be concluded that such scale-free coupled dynamical network can be controlled by one controller.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: The pinning stabilization problem for LCSNNs has been investigated in this paper. A minimum number of controllers have been designed by fully utilizing the structure of the LCSNNs. For the pinning stabilization of LCSNNs with irreducible coupling matrix, only one controller is needed, and controllers are required for the LCSNNs with -reducible coupling matrix. There is no restriction on the structure of the network. Some criteria have been derived for the pinning stabilization of LCSNNs in terms of linear matrix inequalities, which can be efficiently solved by using Matlab LMI toolbox. Numerical examples including scale-free and small-world networks have been demonstrated to show the effectiveness of the designed controllers.

In this paper, all coupled NNs are assumed to be identical. However, in reality, parameter mismatch usually exists between the coupled systems [48]. Therefore, it would be of great interest to study synchronization and pinning control of linearly coupled nonidentical NNs. Synchronization bound error [49], [50] could be a useful concept for the investigation of this issue, since complete synchronization cannot be achieved for nonidentical coupled chaotic systems.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 2. Trajectories of LCSNNs with coupling matrix (58) under controller (49) with a = 4. (a)-(c) Three independent numerical simulations with independent Brownian motions. (d) The average of the above three independent simulations.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
div.p: The authors would like to thank Miss H. Lu and Dr. J. Caldwell for their valuable comments concerning the language improvement. They would also like to thank the anonymous reviewers and the associate editor for their constructive comments, which greatly improved the quality of this paper.

. This work was supported by CityU SRG 7002355, and an international joint project sponsored by the Royal Society of the United Kingdom. He has published more than 120 papers in refereed international journals. His research interests include dynamical systems, signal processing, bioinformatics, control theory, and applications.

Prof. Wang currently serves as an Associate Editor for 12 international journals including the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON AUTOMATIC CONTROL, the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON NEURAL NETWORKS, the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SIGNAL PROCESSING, the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SYSTEMS, MAN, AND CYBERNETICS-PART C: APPLICATIONS AND REVIEWS, and the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON CONTROL SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY.

He has published over ten papers in refereed international journals. His current research interests include collective behavior in complex dynamical networks, multiagent system, chaos synchronization, control theory, and neural networks
